fulltext:
630
Ke : ( ensionen
( quoted on p.  158 ) of the restoration of austere traditions in training which followed on the visit of Apollonius of Tyana,  must remain uncertain,  but it does seem possible that the recruiting of the Agelai by the adoption of Kasens had lapsed for some time and was revived soon after his visit.  If so,  it would confirm the belief that the revival was to some extent artificial,  not so say sentimental. 
To return to the question of the author's equipment for her task : her conscientious re - examination of the ancient authorities,  as has been already indicated,  is not always unbiassed,  and it must be added that her tance with recent publications of importance is very far from adequate.  It is pointed out that the work was completed for the press in 1944,  and that nothing published abroad during the war - period could be utilised.  But we must conclude that some portions of it had not been brought fully up to date even by 1939.  Otherwise we should have expected some cussion of Jaeger^s views on Tyrtaeus and the Eunomia ( in Paideia^ I ),  some knowledge of Ehrenberg * s Neugrmder^ and at least some mention of the works of Aymard and Walbank in reference to the Achaean League,  in chapter I and Appendix II,  to cite only a few obvious examples. 
Besides these omissions there are rather too many signs of a lack of final revision which should have eliminated certain minor,  but irritating sistencies as well as the regrettably large number of misprints to be found in the Greek citations in the footnotes. 
Under the former heading,  we may note that Kolbe's mistaken date for IG» V.  I,  59 is quoted,  and used as evidence for an ( actually imaginary ) difficulty ( p.  201,  n.  z ) though the corrected date is given and definitely accepted on p.  466 ; and IG.  V.  i,  97 is dated to the reign of Trajan ( p.  142,  n.  i ) but to c.  120 / 1 onp.  167 and again,  with additional,  but infact mistaken,  evidence to support it on p.  468 ( App.  IV.  note B ).  As we shall see below,  the first version is the correct one.  Another case,  in which it is difficult to decide whether inconsistency or,  for once,  obscurity of phrasing is responsible,  concerns the interpretation of ( pvXàç <pvXd^avra in the Rhetra.  On p.  421 we read »as the Rhetra clearly lays down,  the number of the tribes was to remain as before ; ( pvXàç ( pvXâ^avxa can have no other meaning«,  whereas on p.  487 we read »The analogy of ( pvM^avxa and ( hßa^avra in the same document,  from ( pvXi ] and ( hßd respectively« etc.  The former passage would seem definitely to imply that the participle came from ( pv^drreiv but the latter clearly alludes to ( pvMCeiv,  But even if the first impression is incorrect,  there is an inconsistency in the use of the two participles,  for qroL is clearly stated to refer to maintaining the old tribes,  whilst ( hß,  was interpreted,  as we have seen above,  as meaning »creating new Obai «. 
Among the commendably few misprints in English which might cause confusion,  on p.  176,  1.  14 for Sparta read Judaea,  and on p.  443 ( No.  15 ) for IG,  203 read IG.  20 В.

label: Chrimes: Ancient Sparta
